title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
text: Adaptive Recovery process reflects asymmetric regulatory dynamic two latent constructs‚Äîstress coping‚Äîactivation one system initiates corrective response . Specifically, stress tends increase coping responses, coping reduces subsequent stress, producing negative feedback loop promotes stability recovery. Individuals differ strength balance cross-regulatory influences, leading variability quickly return equilibrium disturbances. process noise covariance moderate negatively correlated, representing compensatory fluctuations increases stress often accompanied decreases coping, measurement error variance small symmetric across variables. configuration captures psychologically meaningful stress‚Äìresponse mechanism, characterized self-correcting dynamics stabilize system time coordinated asymmetric influences.

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
text: Let t=10100t = 10100 number time points n=100n = 100 number individuals. Let measurement model intecept vector ùõé\boldsymbol{\nu} normally distributed following means (0.80.5)\begin{equation} \left( \begin{array}{c}   0.8 \\   0.5 \\ \end{array} \right) \end{equation} covariance matrix (0.150.050.050.1).\begin{equation} \left( \begin{array}{cc}   0.15 & 0.05 \\   0.05 & 0.1 \\ \end{array} \right) . \end{equation} Let factor loadings matrix ùö≤\boldsymbol{\Lambda} given ùö≤=(1001).\begin{equation} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} = \left( \begin{array}{cc}   1 & 0 \\   0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right) . \end{equation} Let measurement error covariance matrix ùöØ\boldsymbol{\Theta} given ùöØ=(0.05000.05).\begin{equation} \boldsymbol{\Theta} = \left( \begin{array}{cc}   0.05 & 0 \\   0 & 0.05 \\ \end{array} \right) . \end{equation} Let initial condition ùõà0\boldsymbol{\eta}_{0} given ùõà0‚àºùí©(ùõçùõà‚à£0,ùö∫ùõà‚à£0).\begin{equation} \boldsymbol{\eta}_{0} \sim \mathcal{N} \left( \boldsymbol{\mu}_{\boldsymbol{\eta} \mid 0}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\boldsymbol{\eta} \mid 0} \right) . \end{equation} ùõçùõà‚à£0\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\boldsymbol{\eta} \mid 0} ùö∫ùõà‚à£0\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\boldsymbol{\eta} \mid 0} functions ùõÇ\boldsymbol{\alpha} ùõÉ\boldsymbol{\beta}. Let transition matrix ùõÉ\boldsymbol{\beta} normally distributed following means (0.6‚àí0.30.250.7)\begin{equation} \left( \begin{array}{cc}   0.6 & -0.3 \\   0.25 & 0.7 \\ \end{array} \right) \end{equation} covariance matrix (0.0250.01000.010.0200000.020.01000.010.025).\begin{equation} \left( \begin{array}{cccc}   0.025 & 0.01 & 0 & 0 \\   0.01 & 0.02 & 0 & 0 \\   0 & 0 & 0.02 & 0.01 \\   0 & 0 & 0.01 & 0.025 \\ \end{array} \right) . \end{equation} Let intercept vector ùõÇ\boldsymbol{\alpha} fixed zero vector. SimNuN SimBetaN functions simStateSpace package generates random intercept vectors transition matrices multivariate normal distribution. Note SimBetaN function generates transition matrices weakly stationary option set lower upper bounds. Let dynamic process noise ùöø\boldsymbol{\Psi} given ùöø=(0.25‚àí0.1‚àí0.10.22).\begin{equation} \boldsymbol{\Psi} = \left( \begin{array}{cc}   0.25 & -0.1 \\   -0.1 & 0.22 \\ \end{array} \right) . \end{equation}

what: Using the SimSSMIVary Function from the simStateSpace Package to Simulate Data
title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
code: library(simStateSpace) sim <- SimSSMIVary(   n = n,   time = time,   mu0 = mu0,   sigma0_l = sigma0_l,   alpha = alpha,   beta = beta,   psi_l = psi_l,   nu = nu,   lambda = lambda,   theta_l = theta_l ) data <- as.data.frame(sim, burnin = burnin) head(data) #>   id time         y1         y2 #> 1  1    0  1.5073284 -1.3145179 #> 2  1    1 -0.2059357 -0.7482662 #> 3  1    2 -0.1210909 -1.0471269 #> 4  1    3 -0.4246122 -0.9628864 #> 5  1    4  0.3301949 -0.4635634 #> 6  1    5  1.2433061 -0.6266045 plot(sim, burnin = burnin)

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
text: FitDTVARMxID function fits DT-VAR model individual ii. set estimation, first provide starting values parameter matrix.
code: library(fitDTVARMxID)

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
text: autoregressive coefficient matrix ùõÉ\boldsymbol{\beta} given starting values.
code: beta_values <- beta

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
text: intercept vector ùõé\boldsymbol{\nu} initialized starting values.
code: nu_values <- nu

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
text: Covariances psi theta estimated using LDL‚Ä≤ decomposition positive definite covariance matrix. decomposition expresses covariance matrix Œ£\Sigma ùö∫=(ùêã+ùêà)diag(Softplus(ùêùuc))(ùêã+ùêà)‚Ä≤,\begin{equation}   \boldsymbol{\Sigma} = \left( \mathbf{L} + \mathbf{} \right) \mathrm{diag} \left( \mathrm{Softplus} \left( \mathbf{d}_{uc} \right) \right) \left( \mathbf{L} + \mathbf{} \right)^{\prime}, \end{equation} : ùêã\mathbf{L} strictly lower-triangular matrix free parameters (l_mat_strict), ùêà\mathbf{} identity matrix, ùêùuc\mathbf{d}_{uc} unconstrained vector, Softplus(ùêùuc)=log‚Å°(1+exp(ùêùuc))\mathrm{Softplus} \left(\mathbf{d}_{uc} \right) = \log \left(1 + \exp \left( \mathbf{d}_{uc} \right) \right) ensures strictly positive diagonal entries. LDL() function extracts decomposition positive definite covariance matrix. returns: d_uc: unconstrained diagonal parameters, equal InvSoftplus(d_vec), d_vec: diagonal entries, equal Softplus(d_uc), l_mat_strict: strictly lower-triangular factor.
code: sigma <- matrix(   data = c(1.0, 0.5, 0.5, 1.0),   nrow = 2,   ncol = 2 )  ldl_sigma <- LDL(sigma) d_uc <- ldl_sigma$d_uc l_mat_strict <- ldl_sigma$l_mat_strict I <- diag(2) sigma_reconstructed <- (l_mat_strict + I) %*% diag(log1p(exp(d_uc)), 2) %*% t(l_mat_strict + I) sigma_reconstructed #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  1.0  0.5 #> [2,]  0.5  1.0

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
text: Starting values process noise covariance matrix ùöø\boldsymbol{\Psi} given , corresponding LDL‚Ä≤ parameters.
code: psi_values <- psi[[1]] ldl_psi_values <- LDL(psi_values) psi_d_values <- ldl_psi_values$d_uc psi_l_values <- ldl_psi_values$l_mat_strict psi_d_values #> [1] -1.258692 -1.623449 psi_l_values #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  0.0    0 #> [2,] -0.4    0

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
text: Starting values measurement error covariance matrix ùöØ\boldsymbol{\Theta} given , corresponding LDL‚Ä≤ parameters.
code: theta_values <- theta[[1]] ldl_theta_values <- LDL(theta_values) theta_d_values <- ldl_theta_values$d_uc theta_d_values #> [1] -2.970628 -2.970628

what: Initial mean vector (mu_0) and covariance matrix (sigma_0)
title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
text: initial mean vector ùõçùüé\boldsymbol{\mu_0} covariance matrix ùö∫ùüé\boldsymbol{\Sigma_0} fixed using mu0 sigma0.
code: mu0_values <- mu0 sigma0_values <- lapply(   X = sigma0,   FUN = LDL ) sigma0_d_values <- lapply(   X = sigma0_values,   FUN = function(i) {     i$d_uc   } ) sigma0_l_values <- lapply(   X = sigma0_values,   FUN = function(i) {     i$l_mat_strict   } )

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
code: fit <- FitDTVARMxID(   data = data,   observed = c("y1", "y2"),   id = "id",   beta_values = beta_values,   psi_d_values = psi_d_values,   psi_l_values = psi_l_values,   nu_values = nu_values,   theta_d_values = theta_d_values,   theta_d_equal = TRUE,   mu0_values = mu0_values,   sigma0_d_values = sigma0_d_values,   sigma0_l_values = sigma0_l_values,   ncores = parallel::detectCores() ) #> Intermediate files will be saved in /home/ibp5092/work/jeksterslab/devel_fitDTVARMxID/vignettes #> Warning in parallel::mclapply(X = model, FUN = .MxHelperReadRunSave, #> tries_explore = tries_explore, : all scheduled cores encountered errors in user #> code

Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Adaptive Recovery)
code: converged(fit) #> [1] 0.81

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Stable Reciprocal Regulation)
text: Stable Reciprocal Regulation process represents bivariate dynamic system two latent psychological constructs‚Äîpositive negative affect‚Äîmutually influence time. construct shows moderate self-regulation (autoregressive effects) mild opposing cross-effects, reflecting equilibrium-seeking mechanism characteristic emotional balance. Individuals vary self-regulatory tendencies strength antagonistic couplings. population level, transition matrix indicates increases one construct followed slight decreases , producing stable, damped oscillatory pattern around individual equilibrium points. process noise covariance allows small correlated disturbances, measurement errors assumed minimal symmetric across indicators. dynamic pattern captures psychologically plausible process reciprocal inhibition‚Äîshort-term fluctuations one system component (e.g., positive affect) naturally counteracted adjustments counterpart (e.g., negative affect), leading emotional homeostasis time.

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Stable Reciprocal Regulation)
text: Let t=10100t = 10100 number time points n=100n = 100 number individuals. Let measurement model intecept vector ùõé\boldsymbol{\nu} normally distributed following means (0.5‚àí0.5)\begin{equation} \left( \begin{array}{c}   0.5 \\   -0.5 \\ \end{array} \right) \end{equation} covariance matrix (0.1‚àí0.05‚àí0.050.1).\begin{equation} \left( \begin{array}{cc}   0.1 & -0.05 \\   -0.05 & 0.1 \\ \end{array} \right) . \end{equation} Let factor loadings matrix ùö≤\boldsymbol{\Lambda} given ùö≤=(1001).\begin{equation} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} = \left( \begin{array}{cc}   1 & 0 \\   0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right) . \end{equation} Let measurement error covariance matrix ùöØ\boldsymbol{\Theta} given ùöØ=(0.04000.04).\begin{equation} \boldsymbol{\Theta} = \left( \begin{array}{cc}   0.04 & 0 \\   0 & 0.04 \\ \end{array} \right) . \end{equation} Let initial condition ùõà0\boldsymbol{\eta}_{0} given ùõà0‚àºùí©(ùõçùõà‚à£0,ùö∫ùõà‚à£0).\begin{equation} \boldsymbol{\eta}_{0} \sim \mathcal{N} \left( \boldsymbol{\mu}_{\boldsymbol{\eta} \mid 0}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\boldsymbol{\eta} \mid 0} \right) . \end{equation} ùõçùõà‚à£0\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\boldsymbol{\eta} \mid 0} ùö∫ùõà‚à£0\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\boldsymbol{\eta} \mid 0} functions ùõÇ\boldsymbol{\alpha} ùõÉ\boldsymbol{\beta}. Let transition matrix ùõÉ\boldsymbol{\beta} normally distributed following means (0.7‚àí0.2‚àí0.150.65)\begin{equation} \left( \begin{array}{cc}   0.7 & -0.2 \\   -0.15 & 0.65 \\ \end{array} \right) \end{equation} covariance matrix (0.020.01000.010.01500000.010.005000.0050.015).\begin{equation} \left( \begin{array}{cccc}   0.02 & 0.01 & 0 & 0 \\   0.01 & 0.015 & 0 & 0 \\   0 & 0 & 0.01 & 0.005 \\   0 & 0 & 0.005 & 0.015 \\ \end{array} \right) . \end{equation} Let intercept vector ùõÇ\boldsymbol{\alpha} fixed zero vector. SimNuN SimBetaN functions simStateSpace package generates random intercept vectors transition matrices multivariate normal distribution. Note SimBetaN function generates transition matrices weakly stationary option set lower upper bounds. Let dynamic process noise ùöø\boldsymbol{\Psi} given ùöø=(0.2‚àí0.05‚àí0.050.18).\begin{equation} \boldsymbol{\Psi} = \left( \begin{array}{cc}   0.2 & -0.05 \\   -0.05 & 0.18 \\ \end{array} \right) . \end{equation}

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Stable Reciprocal Regulation)
text: Covariances psi theta estimated using LDL‚Ä≤ decomposition positive definite covariance matrix. decomposition expresses covariance matrix Œ£\Sigma ùö∫=(ùêã+ùêà)diag(Softplus(ùêùuc))(ùêã+ùêà)‚Ä≤,\begin{equation}   \boldsymbol{\Sigma} = \left( \mathbf{L} + \mathbf{} \right) \mathrm{diag} \left( \mathrm{Softplus} \left( \mathbf{d}_{uc} \right) \right) \left( \mathbf{L} + \mathbf{} \right)^{\prime}, \end{equation} : ùêã\mathbf{L} strictly lower-triangular matrix free parameters (l_mat_strict), ùêà\mathbf{} identity matrix, ùêùuc\mathbf{d}_{uc} unconstrained vector, Softplus(ùêùuc)=log‚Å°(1+exp(ùêùuc))\mathrm{Softplus} \left(\mathbf{d}_{uc} \right) = \log \left(1 + \exp \left( \mathbf{d}_{uc} \right) \right) ensures strictly positive diagonal entries. LDL() function extracts decomposition positive definite covariance matrix. returns: d_uc: unconstrained diagonal parameters, equal InvSoftplus(d_vec), d_vec: diagonal entries, equal Softplus(d_uc), l_mat_strict: strictly lower-triangular factor.
code: sigma <- matrix(   data = c(1.0, 0.5, 0.5, 1.0),   nrow = 2,   ncol = 2 )  ldl_sigma <- LDL(sigma) d_uc <- ldl_sigma$d_uc l_mat_strict <- ldl_sigma$l_mat_strict I <- diag(2) sigma_reconstructed <- (l_mat_strict + I) %*% diag(log1p(exp(d_uc)), 2) %*% t(l_mat_strict + I) sigma_reconstructed #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  1.0  0.5 #> [2,]  0.5  1.0

title: Fit the Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model By ID (Stable Reciprocal Regulation)
text: Starting values process noise covariance matrix ùöø\boldsymbol{\Psi} given , corresponding LDL‚Ä≤ parameters.
code: psi_values <- psi[[1]] ldl_psi_values <- LDL(psi_values) psi_d_values <- ldl_psi_values$d_uc psi_l_values <- ldl_psi_values$l_mat_strict psi_d_values #> [1] -1.507772 -1.701853 psi_l_values #>       [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  0.00    0 #> [2,] -0.25    0

title: Fit the First-Order Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model by ID ‚Äî FitDTVARMxID
text: Ivan Jacob Agaloos Pesigan

title: Fit the First-Order Discrete-Time Vector Autoregressive Model by ID ‚Äî FitDTVARMxID
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Generate data using the simStateSpace package------------------------------ set.seed(42) k <- 2 n <- 5 time <- 100 alpha <- rep(x = 0, times = k) beta <- matrix(   data = c(.5, .0, .2, .5),   nrow = k,   ncol = k ) psi <- matrix(   data = c(exp(-4.1), exp(-3.9), exp(-3.9), exp(-3.2)),   nrow = k,   ncol = k ) psi_l <- t(chol(psi)) nu <- rep(x = 5, times = k) lambda <- diag(k) theta <- matrix(   data = c(exp(-2), 0, 0, exp(-2.8)),   nrow = k,   ncol = k ) theta_l <- t(chol(theta)) mu0 <- c(solve(diag(k) - beta) %*% alpha) sigma0 <- matrix(   data = c(     solve(diag(k * k) - beta %x% beta) %*% c(psi)   ),   nrow = k,   ncol = k ) sigma0_l <- t(chol(sigma0)) sim <- simStateSpace::SimSSMIVary(   n = n,   time,   mu0 = list(mu0),   sigma0_l = list(sigma0_l),   alpha = list(alpha),   beta = simStateSpace::SimBetaN(     n = n,     beta = beta,     vcov_beta_vec_l = t(chol(0.1 * diag(k * k)))   ),   psi_l = list(psi_l),   nu = list(nu),   lambda = list(lambda),   theta_l = list(theta_l) ) data <- as.data.frame(sim)  # Fit the model-------------------------------------------------------------- library(fitDTVARMxID) fit <- FitDTVARMxID(   data = data,   observed = paste0("y", seq_len(k)),   id = "id" ) print(fit) summary(fit) coef(fit) vcov(fit) converged(fit) } # }

what: LDL' Decomposition of a Symmetric Positive-Definite Matrix ‚Äî LDL
title: LDL' Decomposition of a Symmetric Positive-Definite Matrix ‚Äî LDL
text: Performs LDL' factorization symmetric positive-definite matrix \(X\), $$X = L D L^\top,$$ \(L\) unit lower-triangular (ones diagonal) \(D\) diagonal.

title: LDL' Decomposition of a Symmetric Positive-Definite Matrix ‚Äî LDL
code: LDL(x)

title: LDL' Decomposition of a Symmetric Positive-Definite Matrix ‚Äî LDL
text: x Numeric matrix. Must symmetric positive-definite.

title: LDL' Decomposition of a Symmetric Positive-Definite Matrix ‚Äî LDL
text: list components: l_mat_unit Unit lower-triangular matrix \(L\). l_mat_strict Strictly lower-triangular part \(L\). d_mat Diagonal matrix \(D\). d_vec Vector diagonal entries \(D\). d_uc Unconstrained vector \(\mathrm{softplus}(d\_uc) = d\_vec\). x Original input matrix. y Reconstructed matrix \(L D L^\top\). diff Difference x - y.

title: LDL' Decomposition of a Symmetric Positive-Definite Matrix ‚Äî LDL
text: function returns unit lower-triangular factor \(L\) diagonal factor \(D\). strictly lower-triangular part \(L\) also provided convenience. function additionally computes unconstrained vector d_uc softplus(d_uc) = d_vec, using \(\mathrm{softplus}^{-1}(y) = \log(\exp(y) - 1)\) stable back-transformation.

title: LDL' Decomposition of a Symmetric Positive-Definite Matrix ‚Äî LDL
code: set.seed(123) A <- matrix(rnorm(16), 4, 4) S <- crossprod(A) + diag(1e-6, 4) # SPD out <- LDL(S) max(abs(out$diff)) #> [1] 4.440892e-16

what: Softplus and Inverse Softplus Transformations ‚Äî Softplus
title: Softplus and Inverse Softplus Transformations ‚Äî Softplus
text: softplus transformation maps unconstrained real values positive real line. useful parameters (e.g., variances) must strictly positive. inverse softplus transformation recovers unconstrained value positive input.

title: Softplus and Inverse Softplus Transformations ‚Äî Softplus
code: Softplus(x)  InvSoftplus(x)

title: Softplus and Inverse Softplus Transformations ‚Äî Softplus
text: x Numeric vector matrix. Input values transformed.

title: Softplus and Inverse Softplus Transformations ‚Äî Softplus
text: Softplus(): numeric vector matrix strictly positive values. InvSoftplus(): numeric vector matrix unconstrained values.

title: Softplus and Inverse Softplus Transformations ‚Äî Softplus
text: Softplus(x) = log(1 + exp(x)) InvSoftplus(x) = log(exp(x) - 1) numerical stability, functions use log1p() expm1() internally.

title: Softplus and Inverse Softplus Transformations ‚Äî Softplus
text: Ivan Jacob Agaloos Pesigan

title: Softplus and Inverse Softplus Transformations ‚Äî Softplus
code: # Apply softplus to unconstrained values x <- c(-5, 0, 5) y <- Softplus(x)  # Recover unconstrained values x_recovered <- InvSoftplus(y)  y #> [1] 0.006715348 0.693147181 5.006715348 x_recovered #> [1] -5  0  5

title: Check Model Convergence ‚Äî converged
text: object object class dtvarmxid. ... Passed /used methods. grad_tol Numeric scalar. Tolerance maximum absolute gradient. hess_tol Numeric scalar. Tolerance Hessian eigenvalues; eigenvalues must strictly greater value. vanishing_theta Logical. Test measurement error variance going zero. theta_tol Numeric. Tolerance vanishing theta test. prop Logical. prop = FALSE, named logical vector indicating, individual fit, whether convergence criteria met. prop = TRUE, proportion cases converged.

title: Check Model Convergence ‚Äî converged
text: dtvarmxid method: prop = FALSE, named logical vector indicating, individual fit, whether convergence criteria met. prop = TRUE, proportion cases converged.

title: Check Model Convergence ‚Äî converged
text: Convergence defined three criteria: Status code equals 0L. maximum absolute gradient grad_tol. Hessian positive definite eigenvalues greater hess_tol. vanishing_theta = TRUE, model additionally checks diagonal elements measurement error covariance matrix (\(\Theta\)) vanishingly small, ‚Äúsmall‚Äù defined theta_tol.
